Posts.Content: That is awesomely bad standards -they should be so on top of this. the waiting is the worst bit of all it's like being in limbo. Have you got BC specialist nurse number - they could perhaps talk you through whats happening and re-assure you. Annie
Posts.Title: still waitin

Posts.Content: I was glad to get rid of the cancer and to be honest, with my prothesis in place it's hard to tell whoch one is real and which one false. I have shown my (female) family the scar and let them see what the prothesis is like, I think it is important they understand what is happening - just in case, this bloody disease is so common. The operation wasn't hard to get over, I had lymph nodes removed as well and that left my arm feeling really strange and some reduction in movement. When I had to have an ECG which meant getting top half naked I completely went to pieces, so some body image issues in front of strangers - the radiologist was fab though. I have some other health issues as well so will wait to decide on reconstruction and possible reduction of the real one when I am out of the woods. Good luck with your op
Posts.Title: Mx operation

Posts.Content: Jelly - the pre op is nothing to worry about. there is a lot of questionning about your medical history, previous operations, allergies etc. I had an ECG to confirm heart is ok, a blood test if the pre op is within 7 days of the op, swabbed nasally for MRSI, spoke with the aneasthatist (?spelling), they checked I had signed a consent form, and told what I was having done and why and had my legs measured for the surgical stockings, given those to take with me to wear on op day I was weighed and height checked I think someone talked me thorugh the procedure, what to do pre op re eating and drinking and what would happen to me post op - wake up with 2 drains in and go to the ward - probably home within 3 days (went home day after op with 1 drain in). Think that was all they did, took a while but trekking around the hospital to various departments for tests and then queuing for them took some time. it's a good time to ask questions about what is going to happen.The nurses that do the clerking don't necessarily know about specific procedures but there was the registrar and the aneastheatist (?sp)
Posts.Title: Pre-Op Assessment

Posts.Content: Hi everyone - I have my diagnosis and treatement plan today - single masectomy next Friday with lymph nodes, most likely followed by chemo and tamoxifan and possibly radiation, but he his keeping the decision on the radiation for later. This all started when I had a CT scan for a gyny problem - I get the results and treatment plan for that on Monday. 2 different hospitals of course.So here I am - scared witless but holding it together somehow.
Posts.Title: Newgirl

Posts.Content: Hi Nain, haven't had a bone scan,the CT was easy and quick - and lucky for me as i was being scanned re hysterectomy, they found the tumour in the breast. The MRI scan on your breasts is however Bizarre. Who ever thought that having square cut outs for a woman to dangle her boobs though was a good idea was probably from another planet. I asked the assistant if they had the biggest size available and she replied 'we have never had anyone who didn't fit before' well love, you have now! Another assistant who didn't like to touch my breasts as we struggled to get them in position was so embarassed, and then 40 minutes of something like a star wars battle going on all around you while you lie still and let them shoot! Only the next day when I had an MRI on my pelvis I realised she hadn't actually got the headphones on my ears the first time! Have to say not the best day in my BC experience. Although the telling has made my friends howl with laughter - always the best medicine especially with something as un funny as BC.   Hugs x x x x Annie                       t
Posts.Title: Bone and CT scans

Posts.Content: Oh Fretty - our worst nightmare - I do wish you luck - buckets of it. Never give up hope. Annie
Posts.Title: Wish me luck please

Posts.Content: Hi Sheila. So sorry that you have come to join us. As everyone says this is soooo treatable so don't be dispondant. Everyone seems to have slightly differing treatments so don't be alarmed if your treatment comes in a different order to someone elses, and all hospitals seem to treat differently as well. #This web site is a really good place for advice and support and company of people who have a clue about how you might feel. It is a bewildering whirlwind of a ride but we will all get through it together. Fingers crossed for you on Tuesday, try and think now about questions you might want answered, the ladies on here will give you some ideas if you want. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week- waiting for biopsy results

Posts.Content: thank you all - this is a very lonely and frightening place and having you all there holding me helps. Oh and Eider - you give me the impression I shouldn't google.
Posts.Title: Newgirl

Posts.Content: Bee Sorry you are here with us - I just want to say that I am taking letrezole - can't say that I enjoy the hot flushes a lot and the joint pains are there - but it doesn't stop me doing what I want to do, I garden, I walk long walks, ride my horse and am going back to work this week.  I can do all this but I'm just a bit slow and stiff when I have stopped for a while. Remember that you are unique and that your side effects won't necessarily be the same or as bad as anyone else's and if they are bad talk to the oncology team - that will have lots of solutions for you to help make it easier. My oncology team are pretty damn fab and SO supportive. We are a bit like marathon runners, we have to do it alone but just as we start flagging the support from the people along the route will take your breath away and help you to carry on. Annie
Posts.Title: Letrozole

Posts.Content: brilliant that they have caught it early. I was daunted by the mastectomy but it wasn't anywhere as painful or hard as I thought it would be. in fact probably the easiest bit of my treatment. No-one who doesn't know me well can tell that I have a falsie unless I do something silly like lean over to far! there are bras to hold it in place and prothesises (or is it prothesisii?) come in massive range of sizes, lots of shapes, I just wear camisoles tops under my V neck tops etc - it all seems ok. Once I had the operation I needed to take things easy and have been off work for 10 months - I am due to go back mid August, so if financially you are not struggling you may well find the time useful - you will be able to put yourself first which is probably as steep learning curve for you too. Whatever, good luck with everything and keep coming back here, the support is invaluable. Annie
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer, made redundant 2 weeks ago and...

Posts.Content: Kiera - I had my first FEC yesterday - so far so good, the week before I was really scared. hope you are OK. Annie
Posts.Title: Hello, I'm a newbie

Posts.Content: People are funny - they think it's a compliment to say my hair suits me so short - I feel like a GI with a crew cut and about as feminine. They are surprised, well shocked actually, that I look so well when they see me - sorry how should I look!! They look at my chest and say - oh well you can't tell - well they might not be able to tell but I sure as heck can. and yes they assume that it is all over and I am 'normal' again. And what will happen in the future, my oncologist tells me that I should see my GP about any symptoms which would suggest a return of the cancer - but I never had any symptoms in the first place, I only ever felt ill when they treated me, so how the heck will I know. I am so lost and confused, I kinda think I need you guys more than ever now because you know how it is. My step son knows as well - he had bowel cancer when he was 18, he is 45 now. He said 'no-one understands, no -one knows that you wake up every morning thinking has it still gone or is today the day it shows it's back. So maybe I am lucky because I have someone close who does know what it is like and is willing to hold my hand through the years of 'possibly cured me'.   I hate cancer with a passion.
Posts.Title: All Done ... So what am I ??

Posts.Content: Hi Lindy, welcome to the club. I have spent the last week being a nightmare with mad mood swings as chemo started yesterday and was well scared - but onwards and upwards, it didn't kill me and I don't feel to bad today. Even been thinking about going back to work in Feb when my sick note runs out. You will find lots of people here to supprt you through, to talk to and to laugh and cry with. We can get through this together. Annie
Posts.Title: Hello, I'm a newbie

Posts.Content: I go to bed with a pint glass of iced water and 3 ice packs, which I put under the pillows. When I get a flush I stick an ice pack under my neck, to help me feel cool. the ones under the pillows stay pretty cold until they are needed and I can turn the pillow over and put my head on the cold side - it doesn't last for long but it feels so good. It doesn't stop the flushes but I find it helps me cope. Annie
Posts.Title: Red clover isoflavones for menopausal symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, It is so overwhelming, as if 1 surgery isn't enough having 2 more lined up so soon. I am probably a good bit older than you as my periods finished a few years ago, but I had a full hysterectomy 6 weeks after my mastectomy. I am still reeling and every day look at my scars and think 'how did this happen'. It took some planning and organisation to get fit after 1 op ready for the next, in my case time is critical, and I need to start chemo asap as well. So I have looked at diet and exercise and made sure that I am doing the best I can to help my body cope with it all. Mentally it is a huge rollercoaster , 2 big ops, and in my case 2 diffferent cancers, I am reeling every time I think of the enormity of it all. I think my head will explode sometimes. I can talk about it in little bite size pieces but get very tearful when talking to people outside the family. The hairdresser went into melt down when she said 'what you planning to do with your hair in the future?' and the tears arrived by the bucket full for (to her at least) no apparent reason. But you are right getting it over and done with together does mean back to being you sooner, it's mad how much you can miss doing the things that used to be so routine. Now after the teeth what about a face lift!!!!
Posts.Title: Removal of ovaries

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, I had rads on my neck as well,  advised to use only aqueous cream or E45 on radiation affected areas (no deodorant either on that side for up to 3 weeks afterwards). I have been wearing a very light scarf to keep my neck and ex-boob covered in the sun and have used children's factor 50 on the other side of my chest and neck as they advise not to get burnt near the rads area. Annie
Posts.Title: Suncream & radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hello Lynn, I am not surprised you feel a bit down, I feel as if I am on an out of control rollercoaster. I had a chest and pelvis CT scan for another problem and was called in for the results with some urgency to be told that I had breast cancer. I month later I had a mastectomy and all of the lymph nodes removed from my left side. analysis showed cancer cells in all 20 of the lymph nodes, I am currently waiting for bone scan results. My cancer like yours is lobular, like you I found no obvious signs, on the morning of the mastectomy I felt the area and could only tell there was soemthing there becasue I knew where it was! My mammegramm 2 years ago showed nothing, but the size and the number of lymph nodes affected suggests it had been there for some time. 4 weeks on and I am recovering well, there is some discomfort and I still have the fluid drained off each week - that is not painful. I massage my left arm every morning with oil to keep the skin in good condition and to help prevent the lymphodema that can occur. My body is healing - my mind is still on the rollercoaster. some friends are brilliant and help, some friends aren't really friends at all. Next week I go fo a hysterectomy (the original problem) and hopefully that will not require follow up, but it could be cancer as well. I can only tell you my experiance and what works for me, You are unique and will handle it in your own way but you are not on your own, this disease affects so many and there are many of us here who do perhaps understand some of your agony and anxiety. I have, by chance, a cancer buddy, who I was facebook friends with ( rather than real friends), She is at the end of chemo now and to a great extent she has held my hand as I have gone through these dark weeks. She tells me how things are for her and what has helped her and what hasn't worked for her, she has listened to me cry, laugh, swear shout and has been there whenever I needed someone. I think you will be surprised how many people you already know who have been down this path, perhaps you can find a 'buddy' who knows some of what happens and can help you through. I wish I could tell you that this is all going to be Ok and this is the worst bit. I can't and it isn't but there are lots of us here who will be here through your treatment and help you feel less isolated through it all. big hugs Annie

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny - I am in Nuneaton, having chemo at the Eliot and rads at Cov too. not sure how to private message with my contact details but I am sure there is a way! Annie
Posts.Title: any on near nuneaton

Posts.Content: Doesn't it take forever! I thought mine was never going to grow. I finished rads in early July, my hair is now a thick covering about an inch long all over. I have been wigless for about a month and a half. Annie
Posts.Title: How soon will I get some hair?

Posts.Content: Hi Orange tulip - This treatment takes us all differently - constipation can be a problem so a laxative  before chemo may help -however some chemo may give you the runs so immodium is useful too. I suffered awful pain with the injections you get to boost white cell production so stock up on pain relief but be wary of the ones that cause constipation - see note above. My oncologist told me to have a flu jab the nurse at the surgery nearly laid an egg because I wasn't on the list. But I won and had the injection! Number one thing on my list would be my cancer buddy! if you know or can find someone who has had the same treatment or similar treatment to you that you can ring, text or e-mail at the drop of a hat go for it. at your lowest ebb you having someone who can say 'yes it is awful but it will get easier' is a godsend. This is difficult for you, but your friends, family and acquaintances are really going to struggle and they won't know what to say to you - your cancer buddy will understand how you feel about all the inane, daft and plain idiotic things that  people say to you because they really don't know what else to say. and your cancer buddy is the one person you can be totally honest with, because he/she will know what it's like and you won't have to protect him/her from the truth of what is happening to you. I have been lucky enough to have 2 people to help me through this, You're going to have some peaks and troughs on the roller coaster ride in the chemo weeks but this is the worst bit, so hang in there, you CAN do it. and life  will start to look good again at the other end. Annie
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: Hello Tracey, it is an awful time, waiting for the op and thinking about everything that comes after. you will get through and learn how to cope with the changes to your body, your circle of friends (sadly you learn who are real friends and who are just people you know) and your life. everyone approaches this differently and has different concerns and different pressure points. each of those are as valid and as imprtant to each individual so never feel that you are doing soemthing wrong or being unreasonable etc etc. your are not, this is your illness and your are the one who is dealing with it. the waffle below describes some of my experiences - I hope it helps you and doesn't worry you more. each stage is another step where you learn more about yourself and your world, it isn't all good but it isn't all bad either. I was scared about the op, firstly because my mother died during a life saving operation so i was really frightened that I wouldn't wake up. Secondly I have large breasts (JJ cup) so it was going to be a massive difference. 5 months on I have found some bras that fit well and hold the prothesis, it is quite hard to see which is which - although I think other BC ladies can probably tell! Look at the web sites for bras and talk to the BC nurse about the prothesis. they will give you a 'softy' when you come out of hospital, I found that the weight difference meant I had one boob under my chin and one on my waist when I wore the softy - I think even 'Aunty Gok' would struggle to make that look good. - but Annette the lovely BC nurse sorted me out very quickly and I was wearing the prothesis after a week - and it didn't bother the scar at all, the softy was consigned to the bin soon after that. And don't let the dog chew the prothesis - it gets messy and they don't taste good (apparantly). I have also had to re think my wardrobe - with a knock out cleavage many of my tops were v necks, not ever so low - they do reveal too much now so that neede some thought.but I didn't want to change my style (what little there was) either. I am having chemo and will then have radiation followed by letrazole for 5 years. I had my hair clipped to 1" long when it started to fall out, and now wear a wig or a hat. my husband said it really suited me! What pure white and big bald patches - I know he meant well. I am frustrated that my beard and moustache hairs are taking much longer to stop growing - that seems unfair. The operation wasn't too hard to get over, physically I was quite well and able to cook and clean and walk the dogs fairly soon, got back to normal activity in about 4 weeks although my lovely friends wouldn't let me lift, carry or push too much - how they nag me. For me the mental issues are much harder. I see in my daughters eyes the fear she has, my step son is fantastic but he is scared and shocked. Good friends have suddenly got very busy but I have made some surprising new friends. My husband is himself unwell and is also a very selfish introverted man who really doesn't know how to cope. trying to do things sympathetically to help them is hard and to some extent I have to let them deal with it themselves. My warped, odd sense of humour doesn't help them either. Everyone has different things that they have to deal with. You can get through this, but it is a roller coaster both emptionally and physically, so don't beat yourself upwhen you feel down, cry, get angry, shout etc - and try to put yourself first and think about what you need. that's really hard I think becasue we are so used to putting children, family and work before our own needs - that does have to change now. and remember, treatments have improved, prognosis is improved, breast cancer is survivable. Good luck. Annie

Posts.Title: Just for fun , the lovely things people have done for you ?

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny, no side effects for me, I had 4 weeks of clexane after MX quickly followed by 2 weeks after hysterectomy. apart from bruised tummy and developing a strong dislike of needles have been ok.
Posts.Title: clexane

Posts.Content: It is odd. the hysterectomy is a much bigger op but only 2 weeks of clexane. I took my surgical stockings off after 2 weeks as well and was told I should keep them on for 6 weeks after hysterectomy. there seems to be little consistency in thinking between different teams in the same hospital never mind between different trusts - it makes this journey even more stressful and mind blowing.
Posts.Title: clexane

Posts.Content: Hi Mollydog. I had mastectomy and full lymph node clearance on 21st September last year. The back of my arm and the top and back of my shoulder are still numb, my arm pit still feels thick and odd, but the pins and needles have stopped and the numbness in my fingers has gone.  Do your exercises regularly because that will stretch the tendons and muscles and you will then get more movement back  - I didn't do my exercises and then couldn't lift my arm far so the radiation treatment was very uncomfortable - I have since done them regularly and can lift my arm quite well. the itching and not being able to feel the scratch is just one of those little jokes that this whole cancer thing likes to play on us. Is it worth it? They found cancer in every one of my lymph nodes although mine was a grade 2 which should have meant that it hadn't spread too far. I don't know what I would have done if they had given me the decision to make about whether or not I had them removed - I glad they made the decision for me. In the great scheme of things I can live quite happily with the odd sensations I get in my arm - it isn't painful and it doesn't stop me doing anything I might want although I probably won't take up boxing cos I won't have much  of a left hook! there are other complications but I haven't had any of them so couldn't discuss. Don't beat yourself up for making the decision you made  - it is what it is,you were giving yourself the best shot at living long. So live long and prosper!
Posts.Title: complete lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: I had mine drained 9 times before it finally dried up - felt like I was growing a new boob the first 3 weeks. if you are uncomfortable ask the BC nurse to have it drained - if their procedures are good the risk of infection should be managed. I didn't have to ask becasue it is standard procedure at my hospital - also gives them the chance to check on the wound, that it is healing OK. I think as well they like to see that their lasdies are coping with everything. hopw it clears soon.
